context: [7] 1-3).  [8] 2-Ethylacrolein and 2-ethyl-2-butenal were only degraded by lung cancer cell lines.  [9] A HBEpC-specific feature not found in any of the other investigated cell lines was the degradation of n-octanal, whereas only hFB cells showed a decrease in 3-penten-2-one. [10] It should be noticed that besides the ester n-butyl acetate (and 3-penten-2-one for hFB), nontransformed cells only degrade aldehydes, whereas cancer cells could also degrade nitrogen-containing compounds (pyrrole by A549 and acetonitrile by CALU-1), ketone, and ethers (acetone, methyl tert-butyl ether, and ethyl tert-butyl ether, respectively, all degraded by the CALU-1 line). [1] Overall, the reasons for differences in VOC release or consumption among the investigated cell lines are currently unknown, but may result from phenotypic or genotypic differences. [2] Clarification of this issue will require an understanding of the underlying molecular mechanisms for VOC production, which is currently lacking for the mentioned compounds. Knowledge of the partitioning of organic compounds among different environmental compartments is crucial in evaluating their environmental behavior.
